Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Seasonal Sea Ice Production in the Ross Sea, Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Title: Collaborative Research: Seasonal Sea Ice Production in the Ross Sea, Antarctica (working title changed from submitted title)
Institutions: UT-San Antonio; Columbia University; Naval Postgraduate School; Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute; UC@Boulder

The one place on Earth consistently showing increases in sea ice area, duration, and concentration is the Ross Sea in Antarctica. Satellite imagery shows about half of the Ross Sea increases are associated with changes in the austral fall, when the new sea ice is forming. The most pronounced changes are also located near polynyas, which are areas of open ocean surrounded by sea ice. To understand the processes driving the sea ice increase, and to determine if the increase in sea ice area is also accompanied by a change in ice thickness, this project will conduct an oceanographic cruise to the polynyas of the Ross Sea in April and May, 2017, which is the austral fall. The team will deploy state of the art research tools including unmanned airborne systems (UASs, commonly called drones), autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs), and remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs). Using these tools and others, the team will study atmospheric, oceanic, and sea ice properties and processes concurrently. A change in sea ice production will necessarily change the ocean water below, which may have significant consequences for global ocean circulation patterns, a topic of international importance. All the involved institutions will be training students, and all share the goal of expanding climate literacy in the US, emphasizing the role high latitudes play in the Earth's dynamic climate.

The main goal of the project is to improve estimates of sea ice production and water mass transformation in the Ross Sea. The team will fully capture the spatial and temporal changes in air-ice-ocean interactions when they are initiated in the austral fall, and then track the changes into the winter and spring using ice buoys, and airborne mapping with the newly commissioned IcePod instrument system, which is deployed on the US Antarctic Program's LC-130 fleet. The oceanographic cruise will include stations in and outside of both the Terra Nova Bay and Ross Ice Shelf polynyas. Measurements to be made include air-sea boundary layer fluxes of heat, freshwater, and trace gases, radiation, and meteorology in the air; ice formation processes, ice thickness, snow depth, mass balance, and ice drift within the sea ice zone; and temperature, salinity, and momentum in the ocean below. Following collection of the field data, the team will improve both model parameterizations of air-sea-ice interactions and remote sensing algorithms. Model parameterizations are needed to determine if sea-ice production has increased in crucial areas, and if so, why (e.g., stronger winds or fresher oceans). The remote sensing validation will facilitate change detection over wider areas and verify model predictions over time. Accordingly this project will contribute to the international Southern Ocean Observing System (SOOS) goal of measuring essential climate variables continuously to monitor the state of the ocean and ice cover into the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PIPERS project was an icebreaker expedition into the Ross Sea, Antarctica, in austral winter, 2017, travelling through over a thousand kilometers of frozen ocean to reach the Antarctic coast.  This was only the third time that an icebreaker has ventured deep into the Ross Sea in winter, and the first in almost 20 years. The goals of this project were to better understand what drives the growth of sea ice in autumn and winter, to better understand observed sea ice variability.  This is particularly important, because, unlike the Arctic, sea ice has experienced a somewhat puzzling increase over the past 40 years in this region, only to see a record decline beginning in 2016.  Of particular interest are polynyas - regions along the coast where strong winds blow ice away from the continent. These are regions of prodigious ice production, but have almost never been visited in winter.

The Woods Hole Oceanogaphic Institution component of this project focussed on observations of sea ice thickness from below the ice with a robotic vehicle. This is the first time that an autonomous underwater vehicle has been successfully deployed beneath the Antarctic pack ice in winter.  These observations were paired with measurements on the ice to compare how ice looks like from above, to the ice below.  Combining these data with intensive observations of the snow cover, we were able to better understand how snow distributed on rough sea ice, and so how it might control the thickening of the ice.  An important outcome is we were able to analyze these data with new machine learning techniques to see if a computer can learn how thick the ice is from observations of the sea ice surface alone.  From these results, we were able to develop a method for better determining ice thickness directly from satellite data, which will be an important tool to monitor sea ice thickness in the Antarctic with NASA's new ICESat-2 satellite.

Additionally, we deployed a suite of drifting buoys on the ice that reported data throughout the winter by satellite.  In conjunction with extensive sampling of the ice cover during the cruise, these data showed that the ice in 2017 was abnormally thin, with a thin snow cover. In the past, when freeze-up came earier, the sea ice would develop a thicker ice cover with deeper snow.  The snow, despite its insulating properties, contributes to thickening of the ice cover as it gets inundated with seawater and freezes to form snow ice. In 2017, despite a thinner ice cover that would favor this process, snow ice was rare, and buoy observations suggest little formed until later in spring.  The delayed ice advance also meant that residual heat from the summer remained in the upper ocean, below a relatively shallow cold winter layer at the surface; this heat continued to be mixed up during the winter as observed by the buoys, which limited ice growth throughout the winter.  At the ice edge, ocean heat also appeared to delay the northward advance of the ice edge, so that melting was observed there even in the middle of winter. These data suggest an important role of the ocean in controlling autumn ice advance, which may enhance the lengtheining of the ice-free season, and a reduced sea ice cover as Antarctic sea ice responds to a warming climate.

In the polynyas, particularly in Terra Nova Bay in the western Ross Sea, we observed prodigious ice growth - the fastest growth rates ever observed. Because of the thinner, mobile ice pack, this ice was exported northward quickly, and contributed significantly to the total ice production in the Ross Sea. Combined with observations of ice motion from the drifting buoys, these data suggest that sea ice dynamics may play a more important role in sea ice growth in the Ross Sea than growth at the bottom of the ice pack.

An animated short on the importantce of polynyas for climate and polar ecosystems can be viewed here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=26Wp5VMYl9k
